response.answer_text: Let me tell you a story of two wars. The First Boer War In the First Boer War, the Boers of the South African Republic rebelled against the British Empire. They were of course the underdogs, with the British having far greater numbers and resources. However, they had a few things going for them, such as: Their men were skilled riders and marksmen.They knew the terrain.They had the support of the local population.They were fighting in a remote area, far from British supply lines.The British were occupied elsewhere.When the British did show up to fight, they conducted themselves like gentlemen. They occupied the towns, but this was not much of a problem. Wives and children of rebels continued with their daily lives while their husbands and fathers were doing hit-and-run attacks and killing British soldiers. The Boers won this war, and they reached a peace on terms that the British did not like so much. The Second Boer War When Round 2 broke out 18 years later, it initially seemed that the British had not learned anything from their first tussle with the Boers. Again, they engaged an entire army of skilled marksmen and swift riders, and again, they took heavy losses. But then the British did something very important: they decided not to be gentlemen anymore. This time, when they seized the towns, they did not just make nice with Boer women and children. Instead, they invented the modern concept of the concentration camp. They then rounded up everyone related to the rebels and interned them. Thousands of women and children died from starvation, exposure, and disease, and the rebels’ supply sources disappeared. This broke the rebellion. This time, the Boers were defeated.  Why do I bring this up? How is it relevant? It is relevant in that it shows that a well-supplied global power can, in fact, defeat a determined local force. In fact, it can win in almost every instance. The thing is that it has to be brutal and ruthless. Our engagement with the Taliban in Afghanistan has been anything but brutal and ruthless. We have gone to great lengths to both avoid civilian casualties and to make recompense when we have civilian casualties. In a war in which the combatants are pointing guns at you one day and hoeing fields the next, that can get very convoluted and very messy. Add to this the fact that your enemies are indoctrinated to believe that they will go to heaven and get seventy virgins if they die in battle, and it makes outright victory basically impossible. I am not saying that we should be brutal and ruthless like the British were in the Second Boer War. I am saying that, so long as we are not willing to be brutal and ruthless, we shouldn’t even show up, because it will only be a fiasco. My philosophy regarding national defense and nation-building is simple: If the government of a country does something to harm us, go on a punitive expedition: decimate their armed forces, destroy their infrastructure, and kill their leaders. Then leave. Don’t try to micromanage them after that. Don’t try to root out every last vestige of anti-Americanism. If another evil regime takes power, let them sow their fields with misery. We will stay in our own fields. And if they harm us, we will repeat the process. The petty despots of the world will learn pretty quickly what they will and will not get away with.

Both Pakistan and the United States employed failed strategies. For the American part, it launched a war it could never win because it was dependent upon the one country that opposed its key interests — Pakistan. The United States continued fighting the Afghan Taliban in Afghanistan, when its key vulnerabilities are in Pakistan. At the same time, it built an unwieldy and unsustainable state in Afghanistan whose leadership continued to be corrupt and unresponsive to Afghan needs. Worse, it incentivised Pakistan to continue aiding and abetting America’s enemies through the Coalition Support Funds. If Pakistan had actually delivered, the cash flows would stop.Victory was elusive because Pakistan continued to support the Taliban, and its territory provided them with effective sanctuaries. When pressed, they could always slip across the border and live to fight another day. But Washington was never willing to go the mattresses and force Pakistan to halt its support, and it is not even clear that we could have done that without going to war with Pakistan itself. Washington backed off for very good reasons: US wanted tacit Pakistani cooperation in its not-so-secret drone and special forces campaign against al Qaeda, and They were also worried about regime stability given Pakistan’s nuclear arsenal. Unfortunately, these factors made victory even harder to achieve. Now other reason , Prolonged, large-scale battles are rare. Instead, the war is a slow grind of guerrilla attacks, sporadic gun clashes and the occasional push to overrun a population centre. Homemade bombs – the Taliban’s weapon of choice – continue to spread.Afghanistan is America’s longest war, but it is a war America cannot win. And nowhere is this more evident than in Helmand.   “Even if you kill all the teenagers, the next generation will join the Taliban,” said Abdul Jabbar Qahraman, a former presidential envoy to Helmand. “The insurgency used to be mostly a business. Now it’s also about revenge.” Other reason, US Troops came up to fight a war and what they missed is making the internal Afghan police and army self reliant.Had they spent time on training the people and then supporting them , the success would have been multi folds. Achieving a meaningful victory in Afghanistan — defined as defeating the Taliban and creating an effective, Western-style government in Kabul — would have required sending far more troops (i.e., even more than the Army requested during the "surge"). Troop levels in Afghanistan never approached the ratio of troops/population observed in more successful instances of nation-building, and that deficiency was compounded by Afghanistan’s ethnic divisions, mountainous terrain, geographic isolation, poor infrastructure, and porous borders. 1. The Taliban were easily defeated, and they are consistently defeated on the battlefield. The Afghan government is in place and it is improving every day. 2. The first big problem with eradicating the Taliban is that they are not 'in Afghanistan.' They are based in Pakistan and funded by the Pakistani government. Unless you want to nuke the entire FATAH, the Taliban will still exist.3. The other big problem is that building the Afghan government is a process. You can't just show up in a war-torn, mostly illiterate, and ethnically divided country and just hope to prop up a stable democracy in a day. Or even a decade. That takes time. When the Afghan government fails to provide services, the Taliban gains strength. When the Afghan government demonstrates competence, the Taliban lose power. This is going to take a while.4. Thinking of war as a finite thing is outdated an obsolete. Everyone in America looks at WW2 for an example of what war 'should' be like. That is to say, we fight a war, we defeat the enemy, they surrender, and the war is concluded. This is no longer how it is done. In modern warfare, prolonged insurgency and counterinsurgency will be the norm. That means that even when the enemy is defeated on the battlefield, they will continue to use terrorism and subversion to exercise influence. The only way to 'win' permanently is to establish the supremacy of the Afghan government and eliminate the social and economic factors that drive discontent.
